content.description: Impossibly thin/ blank face climbing in tiny crimps, imbedded pebbles and side pulls. Very fun, but hard
content.location: Northwest headwall next to Money and Calanques

content.description: A great route featuring varied mantles, underclings, and sidepulls. Sustained, giving a very fun, sporty feel.
content.protection: Guidebook says 6 bolts, may be a few more. Anchor is two bolts with rappel rings, on a small ledge.
content.location: The right-most of the three routes (Supprehension, Prophylactic Crowbar, Aqualine) all located on the waterline of the west face of roadside rock (a.k.a. highway rock). The routes are near the southern end of the face, 50 feet north of the small islands the local swimmers call the "Tolon Keys". It is easy to approach by canoe/boat, but also possible to approach by land.

content.description: Starts at a great belay ledge at the top of Kurosawa with spectacular view of the lake. Soak it in before you ascend great quality rock to a small ledge system at the base of Rashomon. Pretty solid 5.8, no real crux per se.
content.location: Accessed via Kurosawa (5.6). Rap down to the obvious belay ledge you started on.

content.description: Beautiful route that needs more traffic to help clean it up.  It has great movement with a little bit of everything: underclings, jams, liebacks, and smearing.  The lichen and gritty rock make this route much harder than the grade.
content.location: This route is to the left of Danton at the top of the grassy ramp in the middle of the face with a long narrow downward pointing flake.  Just to the right of a left facing diehedral.

content.description: Semi slabby with a bouldery start.
content.location: Next to a small tree, about 50 feet up the hill from the Edge. #28 in the book.

content.description: #58  in the book. Pitch goes to the summit of Road Side rock- Fun way to summit
content.location:
Northern terrace, accessed from:

Secrets and Lie backs 5.8 Trad #33

Calanques 10a Sport #43

Money 10c sport  #44

Whatever it costs you 12a #45

Throne of Blood 10c sport #54

Yojimbo 10a Sport #55

Seven Samurai 5.8 #56

content.description: Move up the face, then left and up through a big gray dike. Fun moves.
content.protection: Guidebook says 6 bolts to an anchor and then 3 bolts more to a higher anchor. The midway anchor currently only had one bolt, so going to the top anchor is strongly advised. With a 70m rope one reaches the ground comfortably, so it's fairly certain a 60m rope is fine for lowering/rappeling.
content.location: The middle of the three routes (Supprehension, Prophylactic Crowbar, Aqualine) all located on the waterline of the west face of roadside rock (a.k.a. highway rock). The routes are near the southern end of the face, 50 feet north of the small islands the local swimmers call the "Tolon Keys". It is easy to approach by canoe/boat, but also possible to approach by land.

content.description:
P1 5.9 14 bolts - start up a low angle slab passing a bush on the right side. The climbing eases after the first two bolts and hands and feet always show up just as you need them. The route has a bit of lichen but the key holds are clean. 40M

P2 5.9 - more friction and bolts leads one to the upper terrace in another long pitch. 40M
content.location: Traverse around the south end of the rock slowly gaining height using a series of approach ramps until you are above Creamsicle Buttress. Follow the grassy descending ramp down to the north passing Kurosawa and eventually finding a set of hard to spot rappel anchors. Rap about 80 feet to a grassy ledge. Just to the climber's left of the rappel you will find the start of this route which ascends a dark colored slab.

content.description: Well protected slab with one committing move about halfway up. This is a great way to start a three pitch run to the top of the rock.
content.location: West side of Roadside Rock (Highway Rock in the LaBelle guide). Ascend a gully as you walk around the north side of the peninsula. From the top of the gully, walk west south west towards steamboat rock. There is a short downclimb to a grassy ledge which runs down the west side of the penn to the base of several routes. The Labelle guide (Rock Climbs of Central Washington) has a picture of the approach on page 48 that is helpful.

content.description: Two pitches of banks lake fun times. 30 feet up the gully from the Aqualine belays.
content.location: Directly above ( accessed from ) Supprehension 5.9 / Prophylactic Crowbar 5.9 / Aqualine 5.9.  These are  the water lines on the south west side of the rock.

content.description:
A three pitch route that can be reached by rappelling down the route, using a boat or traversing in from the southwest end approach to reach the base of the climb.

P1, 5.8 - easy climbing up a dirty ramp with 5 bolts to a set of chains under a roof, gear to 1.5" can also be used on this pitch if so desired.

P2, 5.10B - starts off traversing right of the roof (crux) to clip an out of reach bolt then straight up 5 more bolts to a second set of chains under another larger roof.

P3, 5.9 - move out left on an airy traverse around the arête then continue up easy face climbing clipping 10-12 bolts until you top out to a bolted anchor.
content.protection: Bolts, and chained anchors (with the exception of the top pitch which only has bolts for anchors).
content.location: On the North face of Roadside rock there is a large white patch that is cut perpendicular by a chimney. The route starts to the left of the chimney at a large ramp and goes up a right facing dihedral to the left of two large roofs.

content.description:
P1: 5.8 Starts off on the left side of a large flake and traverses right and up on dirty rock before going up a small diehedral to a set of anchor bolts. Watch for rope drag.

P2: 5.8 Move left a couple feet from the anchors to a dirty diehedral with a hand to fingers crack. Finishes up with a move right that takes you out of the diehedral to easy terrain and a set of chains.
content.protection:
P1: Bolts plus gear to 1" with bolted anchor

P2: Bolts plus gear to 2" with anchor chains
content.location: About 50 feet left of Aqualine there is a grassy and rocky ramp that goes left.  Hike almost to the top of the ramp and you will see a large flake behind a bush with a couple bolts on it.  Follow the bolt line up and left. Once on top of the flake there are three variations of the route.  Take the right most bolt line.

content.description:
Creamsicle Buttress is a spectacular route up a proud feature with great rock and good protection at a modest grade. The start is a little complicated to reach, but worth the effort.

The first 40 feet is grubby class 4 to a ledge with a large bush. The climbing improves sharply as you work up and left onto the buttress, following bolts out to the airy buttress edge. The diagonal finger traverse here is the 5.8 crux. Although the route goes in a single lead, there is a bolted anchor around midway. Or belay at the bush, reducing rope drag for a long second pitch to the top. All belays have panoramic views across Banks Lake.
content.protection: Bolts (~15?, I lost count). Descent: From the top of the Creamsicle, a bit of class 4 up and right leads to ledges and easier scrambling to the south. Looks possible to rappel, but more complicated?
content.location: Driving in from the south, the Creamsicle Buttress is prominent as the left skyline of Roadside Rock (see photo).The Buttress starts about 100 feet above the water near the top of the Aqualine crag. Getting there requires walking the main climbers trail around the south end and dropping to the lake edge. Climb one of the three 5.9 routes (Supprehension, Prophylactic Crowbar or Aqualine) or scramble up the gully to the right. From there, walk ~50 feet left to double bolts that start Creamsicle. No doubt there's a scrambling alternative, but it would be just as complicated and less aesthetic.

content.description: Climb past 3 bolts  to a small ledge, step left to the arete and climb delicately up. Great placement and beautiful views.
content.location: The obvious skyline arete on the right side of the northwest headwall. Belay bolt availible

content.description: This is a Banks Lake classic, on the cover of the "Rock Climbs of Central Washington" guidebook. The route climbs the striking arête hanging out over the water. The opening moves up and left are a bit delicate and strenuous, but after that the arête is an easy jug climb in a fantastic position.
content.protection: Guidebook says 6 bolts to an anchor and then 3 bolts more to a higher anchor. I don't remember a midway anchor, it was easy to go to the higher anchor. With a 70m rope one reaches the ground comfortably, so it's fairly certain a 60m rope is fine for lowering/rappeling.
content.location:
The left-most of the three routes (Supprehension, Prophylactic Crowbar, Aqualine) all located on the waterline of the west face of roadside rock (a.k.a. highway rock). The routes are near the southern end of the face, 50 feet north of the small islands the local swimmers call the "Tolon Keys". It is easy to approach by canoe/boat, but also possible to approach by land.

If the water level of the lake is high, it's likely you will be forced into a tenuous traverse to reach the start.

content.description: Optional 3rd pitch to Kurosawa/Seven Samurai. Exposed, easy climbing with great views.
